creditline: Gift of funds from the Paul and Sheila Steiner Charitable Trust
description: portrait of European woman from waist up with cigarette in proper right hand at left; woman has tilted head, facing viewer, brown hair pulled back; woman is wearing a fitted button-up gray coat with brown trim and white lace collar and cuffs; off-white background with blue flowers at L; rectangular ornate gilded frame with vegetal moldings and oval window; D-rings and hanging wire
inscription: R side verso frame, graphite: Westfeldt
markings: TC verso stretcher: AMELLS [gallery label] / ... / Dam med cigarett
signed: lower R, black pigment: Ingeb. Westfelt
text: After seven years spent studying and working in Paris, Ingeborg Westfelt-Eggertz returned to Stockholm in 1890 at the age of thirty-five. She painted this self-portrait around the same time, looking out at the viewer with a self-assured half-smile. Westfelt-Eggertz takes the unusual step of depicting herself with a lit cigarette at a time when smoking was viewed as an unacceptable habit for Swedish women of her status. She does not depict herself simply as a woman artist, holding a paintbrush in one hand, but as a citizen of the world, looking out at the viewer with confidence.
title: Self-portrait with Cigarette
